senses.de: To get rid of all of something by selling it
senses.ex: The concert was so popular that all tickets sold out within a day.

Tips.title: Popularity Indicator
Tips.description: Used when items are quickly bought, showing high demand or popularity.
Tips.example: The new sneakers sold out in minutes!

Tips.title: Limited Availability
Tips.description: Implies that no more items are left to buy, often temporarily.
Tips.example: Sorry, our special edition book has sold out.

Tips.title: No Reservations
Tips.description: Affirms tickets or products cannot be reserved as they're completely gone.
Tips.example: The play sold out so fast, I couldn't even reserve a seat.

senses.de: To abandon one's principles or integrity for personal gain
senses.ex: He was accused of selling out when he signed a contract with a major record label.

Tips.title: Negative Connotation
Tips.description: Often used negatively to criticize a person's actions or decisions.
Tips.example: Fans felt the artist sold out by doing commercials.

Tips.title: Change for Gain
Tips.description: Suggests altering one's behavior or work for money or fame.
Tips.example: She was called a sell out for changing her music style.

Tips.title: Perceived Betrayal
Tips.description: Indicates others see the person as disloyal to their former beliefs.
Tips.example: Old fans accused the band of selling out to the mainstream.

senses.de: A person who betrays their principles for personal gain
senses.ex: Some fans called him a sell out when he started making more mainstream music.

Tips.title: Personal Judgement
Tips.description: Reflects a judgment by others about a person's choices.
Tips.example: After the deal, his colleagues called him a sell out.

Tips.title: Cultural Impact
Tips.description: Can hold cultural weight in discussions about authenticity in arts.
Tips.example: His fans debated if he was a sell out for his movie roles.
